title: Outer Wilds PS4 review – adventures in time and space
text:
Outer Wilds (PS4) – time waits for no alien

One of the year’s best indie games comes to PlayStation 4, with an imaginative mix of Groundhog Day and a sci-fi Majora’s Mask.

Despite having played the game twice now we will never stop confusing Outer Wilds with The Outer Worlds, even as we currently work on a review of the latter. They have absolutely nothing in common, but the names are similar enough that we’ve never been able to talk to anyone else about Outer Wilds without both parties having to clarify which game they mean. It’s an unfortunate state of affairs because Outer Wilds is one of the best and most original games of the year and deserves all the attention it can get.

Outer Wilds was originally released on Xbox One and PC in May but for some reason the PlayStation 4 version was delayed until now. Apart from being £1 cheaper there are no differences, which is exactly what you’d expect given that this isn’t a game that pushes any format in terms of technology (which makes it odd that there’s been no sign of a Switch version).

There’s a link to our full review of the Xbox One version below but the gist of it is that you’re playing as an alien astronaut out minding his own business on a camping trip, when you discover the local sun is about to go supernova in 22 minutes. That’s not enough time to do anything about it and yet when disaster strikes you suddenly find yourself alive again… 22 minutes before the supernova is about to go off.

As a cross between Groundhog Day and Zelda: Majora’s Mask, that’s a great premise for a video game and accordingly Outer Wilds has a very old school charm to it. Despite the scenario there’s no real violence or aggression and you’re given complete freedom to explore and work out the enjoyably complex puzzles on your own. Complex, not in that they’re especially difficulty but because they so imaginatively use the situation and environment (and a few high-tech gadgets) to create a game that’s a pleasure to get lost in.

We’ve no idea if Outer Wilds has been a success or not but it really is one of the best indie games of the year and absolutely worth seeking out on any format.

CLICK HERE FOR THE ORIGINAL FULL REVIEW OF OUTER WILDS

Outer Wilds PS4 review summary In Short: A fantastically imaginative, time-bending puzzle adventure that makes full use of one of the most enjoyably interactive game worlds in a long time. Pros: A great concept, well executed. Excellent world and puzzle design, with secrets and revelations around every corner. Charming visuals and even the few action elements are nicely handled. Cons: Survival element and dialogue with other characters is rather undercooked and it is possible to get entirely stuck at times. Score: 8/10

Formats: PlayStation 4 (reviewed), Xbox One, and PC

Price: £18.99

Publisher: Annapurna Interactive

Developer: Mobius Digital

Release Date: 15th May 2019

Age Rating: 7
